The sound effects were created in a variety of ways:
- John blew bubbles through a straw and into a pan of water.
- Paul and John talked through cans to give the impression of submarine chatter.
- John spoke through the back of his Vox amp in order to sing along with the final verse
- John Skinner and Terry Condon of Abbey Road Studios swirled chains in a bathtub to create the “ocean”.
- The session’s invited musical guests, in addition to singing along with the chorus, created a “party” atmosphere around it all.

And the band begins to play

“After the line, "and the band begins to play”, audio engineer Geoffrey Emerick found a recording of a brass band and changed it slightly so it could not be identified, although it is thought to be a recording of Georges Krier and Charles Helmer’s 1906 composition, “Le Rêve Passe.”

Sky of blue (Sky of blue) and sea of green (Sea of green)
 In our yellow (In our yellow) submarine (Submarine, ha-ha!)

Paul McCartney can be heard talking in the background of this portion of the song.

It is believed that the line “Sky of blue and sea of green” was written by Donovan: a musician, songwriter, and friend of Paul.

Per Donovan in The Beatles Music History –

I helped Paul with the lyrics for ‘Yellow Submarine.’ … he also said that he had another song that was missing a verse.  It was a very small part and I just went into the other room and put together ‘sky of blue, sea of green.’  They had always asked other people for help with a line or two, so I helped with that line.  He knew that I was into kids’ songs and he knew I could help.  I’m sure he could have written the line himself but I suppose he wanted someone to add a line and I added a line… It was nothing really, but he liked it and it stayed in.

We all live in a yellow submarine
 Yellow submarine, yellow submarine

The sailor and his family live a life on the seas, each living in a room aboard the famous ship. It sounds like a dream world, but the song is meant as a story and is overly fanciful. The bright and colorful images just help to drawn children into the story, increasing the free and fun meaning.

In the town where I was born
 Lived a man who sailed to sea
 And he told us of his life
 In the land of submarines

The storyteller grew up near the sea, frequently seeing a man by the docks. While playing one day, the kids find the old man, who begins to tell of his sailing. Interested, they listen to his story about submarines and the high seas.



There is no literal representation of the lyrics in real life.
